SCHOLARSHIPS FOR POLICE OFFICERS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many scholarships and bursaries there are for Police Officers; (b) how many serving officers benefited in the last five years from these scholarships and bursaries; and (c) if there is a career development program me for all officers.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are basically four types of scholarship and bursary schemes for Police officers. They are as follows:

    (a) The Singapore Police Force Scholarship Scheme which, together with the Singapore Armed Forces scholarship scheme, is among the most prestigious scholarships awarded by the Public Service Commission.

    A total of 15 awards have been made under this scheme since it was introduced in 1979.

    (b) The Undergraduate Training Award Scheme for serving Police officers tenable at the NUS, introduced in 1982.

    No award has yet been made under this scheme as the academic requirements are stringent.

    (c) The Undergraduate Bursary cum Study Loan Scheme for serving Police officers tenable at the NUS, which was introduced in 1982.

    A total of seven awards have been made under this scheme; and

    (d) The Commissioner of Police Pre-University Studies Bursary Scheme which was introduced to help the serving junior officers upgrade their academic qualifications.

    A total of 52 awards have been made under this scheme in the last five years.

    In addition, the Public Service Commission also awards Overseas Merit Scholar-

Column: 984

ships, Local Merit Scholarships and Local Merit Bursaries to those who wish to take up a career in the Police Force. Under these schemes, the award holders are appointed as senior Police officers when they complete their University studies. So far, two awards have been made under the Overseas Merit Scholarship Scheme for Police which was introduced last year. In addition, 24 awards have been made under the Local Merit Scholarship and Local Merit Bursary Schemes for Police during the last five years.

    Altogether, 59 serving officers have benefited from the above schemes in the last five years.

    There is a career development programme for Police officers. Their career development is closely monitored by the Career Development Committee in my Ministry. The primary objective of the Committee is to develop every officer to his fullest potential. This is done through a systematic staff appraisal system. Through this, the Committee is able to identify the potential of the officers, chart out their career path and plan and monitor their training, postings and promotion.

    The Career Development Committee identifies and selects suitable officers for training courses based on their potential for development. Besides the scholarships and bursaries, there are a number of overseas and local training courses designed to prepare Police officers for higher appointments and to upgrade their professional competence. Amongst the courses are the Senior Command course, Criminal Investigation course and Instructor Training course conducted in the United Kingdom; the FBI course and the Computer Related Crime Investigation course conducted in the United States; the Crime Prevention course conducted in Japan; the Corporate Crime Investigation course conducted in Australia; the Executive Development Programme conducted by the Canadian Police College and the Non-Graduating course conducted by the National University of Singapore.

    In the same manner, postings of Police officers are closely monitored to ensure better deployment. Depending on the individual's aptitude, inclination, performance

Column: 985

and potential, postings are planned to give them maximum exposure to enable them to assume higher responsibilities. Those who do well and show good potential for further development are recommended for promotion.

LANDSLIDE BEHIND BLOCK 111 DEPOT ROAD


    2. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for National Development if he has ascertained the cause or causes that led to the landslide behind Block 111 Depot Road on Saturday, 3rd March, 1984; what steps will be taken to prevent it from recurring and when these steps will be implemented; and if he can give an assurance that no damage has been done to the structure of Block 111 and that it is still safe.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the landslide behind Block 111, Depot Road, occurred on 3rd March, 1984, after exceptionally heavy and continuous rain on the previous day.

    The slope behind Block 111 was formed by the PUB in the construction of its Mount Faber Service Reservoir. Although an elaborate network of sub-soil and surface drains had been constructed to drain off rain water from the slope, the ground was saturated by the torrential downpour. This weakened the soil and resulted in the landslide.

    The Public Utilities Board has covered up the affected slope with nylon and canvas sheets to prevent further erosion of the soil. The PUB will be cutting back the earth to reduce the steepness of the slope, and will be consulting a firm of soil specialists on additional measures to enhance the stability of the slope.

    The HDB, meanwhile, had cleared the debris from the void deck of Block 111. The Board is now constructing a temporary drain at the toe of the embankment to diven the surface water to an existing drain.

    Site inspection by the HDB engineers have confirmed that the stability of Block

111 has not been affected by the earthslip and that it is safe.

SBCTEXT
(Response)


    4. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (a) whether there is a need for the SBCText Service; (b) if he is satisfied with the response so far; and (c) what are the reasons for the apparent drop in the number of its pages.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, Teletext, which is the generic name for SBCText, is a new growing information medium. It has been introduced in a number of developed countries. If Singapore is to maintain and enhance its position as a communications centre, it must keep apace with developments elsewhere. Communication and information are keys to our position as a financial and trading centre. SBCText can disseminate information faster than any other mass media, be it radio, television or the press. It does not suffer the once-in-24-hours time lag in printing and distribution as in the case of the newspapers. Nor is

Column: 988

SBCText available only at pre-scheduled times as news on Radio and TV.

    Whilst for general use, updating speed may not always be critical, for information say, on stock prices, or financial movements, time is critical. No other medium has the capacity for real-time up-dates that SBCText has. For example, when the SBCText computer is interfaced with the Stock Exchange computer in June this year, up-to-date movements will be available to those with access to SBCText.

    The pilot service aims at meeting a broad range of interests. There is something for all on SBCText - for the family at home, for the professional in commerce and industry, and for our visitors and tourists. For the householder, the pages of SBCText contain news, news flash, cultural guides, consumer information, health guide, sports news, Radio and TV highlights, etc. For the commuter, the traveller and the tourist, there are guides on SBCText for bus routes and taxi services apart from airline flight schedules which are directly interfaced with the computer in Changi Airport, etc. For the investing public and the business community, there are more than 40 pages of financial news - stock prices, gold and commodity prices, round-up of stock exchanges, exchange rates, etc. There are, in addition, more than 10 pages of shipping information.

    The editorial approach adopted by SBCText caters to those who require news quickly and concisely as well as those who require detailed information.

    Response to the service has been slow but this was not unexpected. There is a cost to having a teletext feature in a TV receiver. The present cost differential between a TV set with and without the capacity to receive teletext is high. This will change over the next few years. Most consumers will only consider the teletext service when it is time to buy a new TV set to replace their old set. I expect that it will be about five to 10 years before most Singaporeans will have TV sets with the capacity to receive teletext. All of us involved in this service have been aware that teletext is an innovation that has to be given time to penetrate in our society.

    During the present pilot phase, SBC is striving to improve the service as well as to educate the public on the features and benefits of SBCText. Even TV dealers are being put through an SBCText familiarization course.

    The convenience, usefulness and the speed with which information can be provided and updated vis-a-vis the other mass media and the fact that there is no additional operating cost to the viewer-reader, will eventually win more users of SBCText.

    There is no "drop in the number of pages on SBCText." On the contrary, the number of pages of editorial matter has been increasing. FOREIGN WORKERS
(Particulars)


    5. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Acting Minister for Labour whether he will give the number of foreign workers employed in Singapore under Work Permits as at 1st March, 1984 in (i) the Construction industry; (ii) the Manufacturing industry; (iii) Oil industry; (iv) Transport, services and related industries; and (v) as Domestic servants.

     The Acting Minister for Labour (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are approximately 150,000 work perm it holders in Singapore, including permanent residents.

    The details sought by the Member are not available. While the Ministry has admi-

Column: 990

nistrative records of work permit holders, it is not possible to accurately state the number of such workers at any given time, because many leave without informing the Ministry. To give accurate figures and the breakdown sought requires a time-consuming and complicated exercise which is both costly and unproductive.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two questions to ask the Acting Minister. May we know when we can get this information? The Minister may consider it unproductive but, with respect to him, I think this House is entitled to the information if it is sought. And I must insist on an answer to that question. So may we know when we may have this information that has been asked for?

    Secondly, would the Minister state whether the wages paid to these foreign workers are lower than the wages paid to Singaporeans? I have a purpose in asking this and would he answer that first?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think he should know that the wages paid to foreign workers or local workers are determined by market forces. They are not paid by the Government.

    Secondly, as to when can we give the information, I see no reason whatsoever in deploying large numbers of my staff from whatever work they are doing and to spend time, money and expensive computer time in churning out the information just for the gratification of the Member's debating or publicity desires.

    Even if the figures are available, I doubt whether any useful purpose is met in giving these to him. We have had previous instances where my Ministry or other Ministries had laboured to give figures. Has he proved himself responsible? Has he used the figures for public interest, in Singapore's interest? On the contrary, the record has shown that he is out to embarrass Singapore internationally with his attempt to fabricate, even concoct, figures for the international press about thousands starving in Singapore. Did he then come to the House to ask for figures? Did he ask for figures before he gave that interview?

    So, Mr Speaker, Sir, no over-riding public interest is advanced in my Ministry

Column: 991

spending a large amount of its manpower and time in giving him the figures.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will ignore all this tirade from the Acting Minister for Labour. It is completely irrelevant and just utter verbiage. But this is a point of principle, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: Your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I want a ruling as to whether I am entitled to this information or not as a Member of this House. Are we going to be told, "You can't have this information"?

    Secondly, unless they want to hide figures or information from the public, I do not know why the Acting Minister is not able to tell me whether foreign workers are being paid less than the Singapore workers. Does he know that some Singapore workers are being displaced because foreign workers are cheaper?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a fact known not only in Singapore but elsewhere that we have a full employment situation. And because we have a labour shortage, it is necessary to import large numbers of foreign workers. I see no reason in giving him any information more than what I have already supplied. What every Singaporean needs to know is that there is a large number of foreign workers, 150,000, and we have to have them temporarily. But in the long-term economic and social interest, they will have to be phased out. The Government will phase them out. But while they are here, the Government will take strong measures to ensure that they do not sink roots here, whether or not the Member for Anson takes up cases for them for extensions and marriage restrictions or advances exceptions to policy and special circumstances for foreign workers to sink roots here. He may advance the cause of foreign workers but we as a Government have to be firm.

tion. Is a Member of the House entitled to information or not? That is one.

    Second, will he please answer this question : Is it not within the knowledge of the Ministry that foreign workers are paid less than Singapore workers and what steps is he taking to ensure that Singapore workers are not being displaced?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not propose to labour the point. I have answered his questions. I have gone through the Standing Orders. Standing Orders permit him to ask any question.      Mr Tang See Chim (Chua Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, just before the Moment of Interruption yesterday I was urging the Minister for the Environment to direct his Hawkers Department to coordinate with the Resettlement Department so that when an area is to be resettled the hawkers serving that area should be resettled together with the residents so as not to leave the hawker centre or the market as a ghost centre or market.

    I was also telling the Minister that, in respect of farmers in their advanced years who have always been farmers and who know of no other trade, the Hawkers Department should take their plight into consideration when processing their applications for hawkerstalls. I would now urge the Minister to take a very sympathetic view of these farmers who have been displaced and who have applied for hawker stalls. He should be sympathetic and consider allocating them hawker stalls.

    In my experience in the Meet-the-People sessions, Sir, most of these displaced farmers who have applied for hawker stalls do receive very polite replies, but invariably the reply is that they do not qualify for a hawker stall. And in the rare instances where they do qualify, the offer is for a market produce stall rather than for a cooked food stall.

    Sir, surely this is an indication that there is a demand for cooked food stalls. I think this is indicated by the general economic condition of society, especially when the Government is urging housewives to go out to work. This would, in fact, be one way of inducing housewives to go out to work so that when they come home there is a market stall ready to serve them with cooked food. This is certainly better than to insist that the displaced farmers accept market produce stalls. Then the housewives would still have to do the cooking

themselves. So I would urge the Minister to reconsider the whole policy on hawkers so as to be in tune with the changing economic conditions of Singapore. Not only that, it would also help the people who are displaced as a result of resettlement.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the subject of hawker licence and hawker stalls has already been touched, may I have your permission to speak now instead of moving amendment No. (5)?

     The Chairman: All right.

     Mr Chandra Das: Sir, I would like to seek some clarification from the Minister for the Environment with respect to hawker licences and hawker market policies. Firstly, Sir, the percentage of Singaporeans who eat outside nowadays is fairly high. I am wondering, in view of this development, what steps are being taken to further improve the general environment of our hawker centres as well as the hygiene of our hawkers.

    Sir, as stated by the hon. Member for Chua Chu Kang we are flooded with requests in our meet-the-people sessions for cooked food hawker stalls. Whilst a hawker licence is granted fairly easily to sell poultry, market produce or sundry goods, the request for cooked food is usually rejected. Obviously I feel that there is a surplus of stalls in the wet markets and an acute shortage of stalls to sell cooked food in the hawker centres. Maybe the Minister would like to enlighten the House on this subject.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Teo Chong Tee): Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    Before the House rose yesterday, the hon, Member for Thomson touched on the indiscriminate spitting in Singapore. Let me first deal with this problem.

    Sir, I share the concern of the Member for Thomson that indiscriminate spitting in public places is a despicable anti-social habit which can give rise to public health risk. It cannot be condoned. Those who spit in public places are committing an offence under our Public Health regulations and can be prosecuted. However, there are practicable problems involved in catching them in the act. In any case, the problem cannot be eradicated through enforcement and prosecution. Social pressure must be applied on these people to change.

    My Ministry can step up its enforcement action but this is not expected to be effective. In the case of those spitting from their cars, members of the public can help by providing my Ministry with the relevant particulars, such as the car registration number, the place, the date and the time of the incident, and we will definitely prosecute the culprits, We can even publicise the cases to act as a deterrent to others. Besides this, we will also organize public health education programme to focus on this problem.

    Let me now deal with the hawker matters which have been raised by the hon. Member for Chua Chu Kang and the hon. Member for Chong Boon. Hawkers who are plying on the streets are conducting their business under unhygienic conditions. The street pitches do not have the basic facilities, such as electricity, water and gas supplies, toilet facilities, anti-pollution measures and proper disposal of refuse. In 1971, the Government decided to build markets and food centres to house these street hawkers. These markets and food centres are provided with all the basic facilities.

    In 1981, a study team chaired by the former Senior Parliamentary Secretary of my Ministry and comprising Members of Parliament and officials from the Ministry of the Environment, Primary Production Department, HDB and the Ministry of Trade and Industry, was set up to review the existing retail distribution system. In

Column: 996

their review, the study team recommended that wet markets be replaced by supermarkets, specialty and neighbourhood stores. My Ministry has not built wet markets for many years and HDB has also stopped building wet markets in their new housing estates. It has also been decided that no more new food centres will be built in the future by the Ministry of the Environment or the HDB.

    There are at present some 1,077 licensed street hawkers, most of them are selling cooked food. They will be relocated in food centres that are now under construction and those food stalls that will be converted from vacant market produce stalls. My Ministry proposes to convert about 88 market produce stalls at Cuppage Road and Queens Crescent Market into 44 cooked food stalls. In addition, HDB has plans to convert 688 vacant market produce stalls into 243 cooked food stalls in their markets and cooked food centres.

    My Ministry will not issue any more new hawker licences for cooked food stalls except for genuine hardship cases. There are still some 853 licensed cooked food hawkers operating from street pitches. All the available vacant stalls in existing markets and food centres are reserved for them. Due to the limited number of cooked food stalls available, hardship cases are accorded a lower priority. As there is a surplus of market produce stalls in the existing markets, applicants under hardship cases are usually offered such stalls.

    In 1983, my Ministry received a total of 4,844 applications for hawker licences on grounds of hardship. Of this number, only 106 cases were approved. The present hardship criteria are intended to ensure that only genuine hardship cases will be given hawker stalls. It is not my Ministry's policy to give any special consideration for people affected by resettlement, for example, farmers, squatters, etc. We can, however, review the criteria after all street hawkers have been relocated. The alternaive to obtaining a hawker licence for cooked food stalls is to rent a stall in eating establishments. Generally, the business of cooked food is fairly lucrative and operators could afford the higher rental charges for a stall in eating establishments.

    In the case of stallholders who were living in Chua Chu Kang constituency and who have been resettled in the Jurong area, we will look into their request for stalls in the Jurong West or Jurong East Market. However, as all the stalls in these two markets have been reserved for the relocation of street hawkers and stall holders in existing markets and food centres that have been affected by public redevelopment schemes, we are unable to accommodate their request at this point of time. We may, however, consider their request for stalls in these two markets only if there are vacancies after the stalls have been ballotted.

    My Ministry maintains 61 markets and food centres. Improvements to these centres are also carried out as and when necessary. In FY 83 my Ministry spent $1.3 million to improve the general environment of our hawker centres compared with $151,000 and $846,000 in FY 82 and FY 81 respectively.
